papers.title: Propulsion Trades for a 2035-2040 Solar Gravitational Lens Mission
papers.abstract: The Solar Gravitational Lens (SGL) enables multipixel imaging and spatially resolved spectroscopy of a nearby terrestrial exoplanet from heliocentric distances z eq 650-900 AU, where solar power is negligible and transportation largely sets time-to-first-science. Reaching 650 AU in 20 yr implies a ballistic lower bound vr eq 32.5 AU/yr eq 154 km/s, motivating propulsion beyond chemical and gravity-assist-only options. We compare close-perihelion solar sailing, fission-powered nuclear electric propulsion (NEP), and Oberth-enabled hybrid injection using simple time-to-distance models that isolate the long outbound leg (i.e., excluding architecture-dependent inner-solar-system injection overhead). For solar sailing, r‚Çö=0.05 AU requires œÉ t‚Çít eq 4.9 g\,m‚Åª¬≤ for v_‚àû eq 105 km/s and œÉ t‚Çít eq 2.3 g\,m‚Åª¬≤ for v_‚àû eq 155 km/s, placing sub-20 yr sail-only access in an ultra-low-areal-density, deep-perihelion survivability regime. For NEP, a constant-power stage closure shows that a m‚ÇÄ=20 t spacecraft with m ‚Çö‚Çêy=800 kg and Œ∑=0.7 reaches 650 AU in 27-33 yr for Œ± t‚Çít=10-20 kg\,kW‚Çë‚Åª¬π (typical optima P‚Çë eq 0.18-0.30 MW‚Çë, thrust of a few newtons). NEP-only sub-20 yr transfers require extremely aggressive assumptions (Œ± t‚Çít 3 kg\,kW‚Çë‚Åª¬π and very-high-I s‚Çö, long-life EP), whereas hybrid architectures become plausible for Œ± t‚Çít 10-15 kg\,kW‚Çë‚Åª¬π if an injection stage supplies v‚ÇÄ 50-70 km/s prior to NEP cruise. We map these requirements to technology readiness and identify system-level demonstrations needed by the early 2030s for a credible 2035--2040 start.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine being able to take detailed photos of planets orbiting other stars‚Äînot just detecting them, but actually seeing their surfaces, weather patterns, and atmospheric composition. This breakthrough could help us answer one of humanity's most profound questions: Are we alone? Scientists have identified a clever way to use our own Sun as a giant magnifying glass to photograph Earth-like planets around nearby stars. The catch? We'd need to send a spacecraft farther from home than anything we've ever launched before, traveling over 20 times the distance to Pluto. This research tackles the engineering challenge of how to get there fast enough to make such a mission worthwhile.

**What They Did**

The researchers studied three different ways to propel a spacecraft on this epic journey to a point roughly 650 times Earth's distance from the Sun. They compared ultra-lightweight solar sails that would dive dangerously close to the Sun to catch maximum sunlight, nuclear-powered electric engines that would push steadily for decades, and hybrid approaches combining different propulsion methods. Using mathematical models, they calculated how long each approach would take and what technologies would be needed, focusing on realistic engineering constraints rather than science fiction concepts.

**Key Findings**

To reach the target distance in under 20 years, a solar sail would need to be incredibly thin‚Äîlighter than tissue paper‚Äîand survive a scorching close approach to the Sun at just one-twentieth Earth's distance. Nuclear electric propulsion alone would take 27-33 years with current technology, requiring massive power systems weighing 20 tons but producing thrust gentler than the weight of an apple. The most promising approach combines an initial high-speed boost with nuclear-powered cruising, potentially cutting the journey to under 20 years if the technology advances sufficiently.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides the first realistic roadmap for humanity's most ambitious space mission. Success would revolutionize exoplanet science, potentially revealing alien continents, oceans, and atmospheres in unprecedented detail. The timeline is tight‚Äîkey technologies must be demonstrated by the early 2030s for a launch later that decade.

papers.title: A Two-Dimensional Analytic Solution for the Generation of Hyperbolic Trajectories Via A Single Close Encounter with Applications To Interstellar Objects
papers.abstract: The discovery of interstellar interlopers such as 1I/`Oumuamua, 2I/Borisov, and 3I/ATLAS have highlighted the necessity of understanding the dynamical pathways that eject small bodies from planetary systems into hyperbolic trajectories. In this paper we examine the orbital elements of particles in the restricted three-body problem prior to and post scattering onto hyperbolic trajectories by massive perturbers. Building on previous work, we calculate closed-form -- but approximate -- analytic criteria that map pre- to post-encounter orbital elements. An application of these equations demonstrates that ejection occurs most efficiently when the orbital eccentricity of the massless test particle exceeds a minimum threshold, e0.4. The primary driver of the final eccentricity is the component of the perturber-centric velocity projected along the direction of motion of the perturber. These analytic criteria are then benchmarked and validated against numerical simulations which demonstrate that they provide a reasonably good zeroth-order approximation for ejection behavior. However, system-specific cases will generally require numerical simulations in addition to this analytic construction. The methodology is applied to (i) the solar system and exoplanetary systems (ii) Œ≤ Pictoris and (iii) HR 8799 to evaluate the pre-scattering orbits of ejected particles. This method provides a transparent and computationally efficient tool for identifying orbits within a given system from which interstellar objects are efficiently ejected via a single scattering event from a massive perturber.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

In recent years, astronomers have spotted mysterious visitors racing through our solar system‚Äîobjects like 'Oumuamua and Borisov that came from other star systems entirely. These "interstellar interlopers" raise a fascinating question: how do rocks, asteroids, and comets get kicked out of their home solar systems and sent flying through the galaxy? Understanding this cosmic game of pinball isn't just academic curiosity‚Äîit helps us piece together how planetary systems form, evolve, and interact. Plus, if objects are being ejected from other systems and landing in ours, our solar system is likely doing the same thing, flinging material toward distant stars and potentially spreading the ingredients for life across the galaxy.

**What They Did**

The researchers created mathematical formulas to predict how small objects like asteroids get ejected from solar systems. Think of it like working out the physics of a billiard shot‚Äîif you know the speed and angle of the cue ball hitting another ball, you can predict where that second ball will go. Here, the "cue ball" is a massive planet, and the target is a much smaller asteroid or comet. The team developed equations that can quickly calculate what happens when a planet's gravity gives a small object such a powerful kick that it escapes the star system entirely. They tested these formulas against computer simulations and applied them to our solar system and two other known planetary systems.

**Key Findings**

The research revealed that ejection works best when the small object already has a stretched-out, oval-shaped orbit‚Äîspecifically, when its "eccentricity" (a measure of how oval vs. circular an orbit is) exceeds 0.4. Objects on more circular orbits rarely get ejected. The final speed and direction of ejected objects depends heavily on how the planet and asteroid are moving relative to each other during their close encounter. The team's equations successfully predicted ejection patterns in multiple star systems, providing a cosmic "recipe" for creating interstellar wanderers.

**Looking Forward**

This research gives astronomers a powerful shortcut for identifying which regions of any planetary system are most likely to produce interstellar objects. Instead of running lengthy computer simulations, scientists can now use these formulas to quickly map ejection zones around different types of planets and stars. This could help us predict how many interstellar visitors we might expect to see, understand the cosmic recycling of planetary building blocks, and even estimate how often potentially life-bearing material gets shared between star systems across the galaxy.
